awd_titl_txt: RAPID: Population Protection and Monitoring in Response to Radiological Incidents
awd_abstract_narration:
Proposal #:	CNS 11-38733
PI(s):		Lee, Eva K	
Institution:	Georgia Tech Research Corporation
Title: 		Population Protection and Monitoring in Response to Radiological Incidents		
Project Proposed:
This RAPID project, collecting rare and real-life data pertaining to radiological emergency response in Japan, builds on previous work that collects and processes a large amount of time-motion study data in the public health emergency response system planning and usage at Georgia Tech.   The team will work with Japanese collaborators in their efforts in performing assessment of the recent series of disasters in Japan, as well as in assisting in the recovery. This team is experienced in using a real-time information-decision support system for emergency preparedness. The collection and the analysis of scarce data in the so-called Knowledge Data Bank for Radiological Responses, speaks to the importance and uniqueness of the proposed system. The Japanese-USA academic research team will be engaged in some of the following activities: 
-	Establish a knowledge data bank for radiological response: emergency data collection and resource assessment. 
-	Process mapping and time motion study.
-	Interview individuals (emergency workers, affected individuals, etc.)
-	Incorporate the radiological knowledge data bank into a real-time simulator and decision support system. 
-	Analyze and assess the effects of the disaster in collaboration with NanZan University.
The final system will facilitate assessment of current operations performance versus pre-disaster preparedness. It will allow for the study, training, and enhancement of emergency response, as well as future planning for radiological incidents. The work provides a unique opportunity to collect on-the-ground emergency response data. 
The researchers collaborate with the Japanese investigators from NanZam University, Dr. Suzuki and Dr. Sasaki, whose work is funded by the Japan Society of Promotion of Science. The Japanese team will arrange trips for the US team to visit the various shelters, distribution, medical, and/or health-registering sites where they will conduct the time-motion studies, interviews, and operations/performance observations, and evaluations. A letter of support and biographical sketches of the Japanese collaborators are included in the supplementary document.  
Broader Impacts: 
This project promises an immediate benefit to society by supporting economic recovery efforts in Japan through a participatory research paradigm. The data bank is critical to our national medical preparedness, emergency response, and homeland security. Moreover, the work is urgent for population protection from nuclear plant accidents. Long-term benefits for future disasters are in evidence. Obviously, the emergency response and disaster mitigation research will be enabled with the developed simulation and decision support system along with the knowledge data base. In general, the project also contributes to train graduate students exposing them to high-impact application areas.

por.por_cntn:
Population protection and emergency response is multi-faceted. It involves identifying people in immediate danger, identifying people who need medical treatment for contamination or exposure, recommending and facilitating practical steps to minimize risk, registering people for long-term health monitoring, and servicing the displaced population on day-to-day needs.

 

This NSF-RAPID project focuses on the Fukushima radiological disaster after the 2011 9.0 Tohoku earthquake. The earthquake triggered a 15-metre tsunami, which disabled the power supply and cooling of three Fukushima Daiichi reactors, causing a major nuclear accident. The goals were to collect on­the­ground response and health monitoring data? provide advice and technology for effective and efficiency screening and decontamination? and design and advance information – decision support system for rapid population protection and emergency response for radiological incidents.

 

The project was conducted in collaboration with Japanese investigators, Dr. Suzuki and Dr. Sasaki from NanZan University. The team traveled to  temporary shelters, distribution/medical sites, and health registering and screening sites to conduct time-motion studies, interviews, and operations / performance observations and evaluations.

 

Notably, Lee was among the first US scientist to have interviewed citizens living within 15 miles of the Fukushima nuclear plants. She collected critical data regarding timelines for evacuation, screening, health status, radiological awareness and sociological information of this local population, including family members of workers at the nuclear plant. The data also includes subsequent psychological and medical impacts on this population.

 

In an interview with over 1000 families living within 15 miles from the disrupted nuclear plants, only a quarter of them have some radiation emergency response knowledge. Nine months after the initial radiological accident, only 27% of the affected population has been screened. Among them, about 23%  received medication. This underscores the urgency to improve and advance the operational capability for screening and health monitoring.

 

Along with data collection, the Georgia Tech team designed and developed a real-time simulation-optimization decision-support system, RealOpt-CRC. The system can be used and tailored for studying various infrastructures, including emergency response due to man-made or natural disasters. Specifically RealOpt-CRC enables emergency planners to:

  1. determine efficient resource allocation and operations for rapid screening and emergency response, accommodating on-the-fly changes as the situation evolves;
  2. monitor within-center cross contamination and provide guidance on dynamic triage responses to minimize it;
  3. train regional radiation safety and public health personnel on emergency preparedness and familiarize them with procedural steps for screening and decontamination, and emergency services;
  4. analyze and assess the adequacy of existing resources (locally and/or regionally), and identify budget and labor needs to accommodate emergency responses;  
  5. maximize throughput under resource constraints during real situations;
  6. estimate costs and resources needed for the protection of the general population; and
  7. perform large-scale virtual exercise.

 

Since 2011, the system has been disseminated to public health emergency coordinators for planning purpose. The system allows rapid planning and resource optimization that improve the throughput and operational effectiveness and efficiency during disaster incidents.
